awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An integrative approach to understanding the evolution and systematics of Chalcidoidea: A recent megaradiation of Hymenoptera
awd_abstract_narration:
Chalcidoidea (jewel wasps) are among the most species rich, ecologically important, and biologically diverse groups of terrestrial organisms. Their diversity is staggering, with more than 500,000 species thought to exist. These minute wasps (mostly 1-2 mm in size) are numerically abundant and common in almost every habitat. The smallest of these wasps are smaller than a typical single-celled organism, and yet the adults can fly, locate their hosts, deposit their eggs, and as larvae, consume their insect hosts. Most chalcidoid wasps are parasitoids; they feed on their insect hosts, eventually killing them. A few groups have also evolved to attack plant hosts and some serve as pollinators. Species attack all life stages from eggs to adults, and live and feed either internally or externally. Some are parasitoids of other parasitoids and some may even feed on their own species. Because they kill other insects, these wasps are extremely important for the control of pests of agricultural and forest crops, as well as vectors of human disease and veterinary pests. The economic importance of these wasps in pest management is unparalleled. They are widely used in biological control programs against major pests, with outcomes documented to result in decreases in pesticide, increases in yield, and in landmark cases direct savings of billions of dollars or permanent pest control. The evolutionary events leading to this enormous diversity in morphology, biology and rates of diversification are poorly understood, leading to an artificial system of taxonomic classification. In this research project, researchers will use a diverse array of molecular, morphological and bioinformatics approaches to develop a solid understanding of the hierarchy of relationships across the entire group. These relationships will then be used to reclassify major groups to reflect common ancestry, to provide a framework for a web-accessible portal to manage and deliver information on their diverse biology, and to explore the evolutionary changes that have driven and shaped this enormous radiation of terrestrial insects.

The objectives of the research project are to 1) generate a robust molecular phylogeny of the Chalcidoidea using new data from transcriptomes and targeted DNA enrichment for over 400 species, 2) generate morphological data for over 200 fossils from Eocene and Cretaceous amber and combine these with a comprehensive morphological data set for extant taxa, 3) develop a revised classification of Chalcidoidea in book form through a series of workshops and worldwide collaborations, and 4) make available information on the taxonomy, biology and distribution of over 31,000 available names and information in over 40,000 references. The project will train two postdoctoral researchers, one graduate student and several undergraduates. To involve the wider scientific community, a worldwide group of biocontrol researchers and taxonomists will develop a new classification for Chalcidoidea. With groups of Research and Extension Specialists, the project will develop posters, fliers, specimen education kits, and other educational materials for use in the classroom and by extension specialists, agricultural advisors, master naturalists  and master gardeners, and the general public to develop a greater interest and understanding of this charismatic and and important group of insects.

por.por_cntn:
Chalcidoidea (jewel wasps) are among the most species rich, ecologically important, and biologically diverse groups of terrestrial organisms. Their diversity is staggering with 27,859 described species and 2,188 genera currently recognized. However, even this is clearly an underestimate of the true diversity, and more than 500,000 species are thought to exist in nature. These minute wasps (mostly 1-2 mm in size) are numerically abundant and common in almost every habitat. The smallest of these wasps are smaller than a typical single-celled organism (much smaller than the dot at the end of this sentence), and yet the adults can fly, mate, locate their hosts, deposit their eggs, and as larvae, consume their insect hosts. Most chalcidoid wasps are parasitoids; they feed on their insect hosts, eventually killing them. A few groups have also evolved to attack plant hosts and some serve as pollinators. Species attack all life stages from eggs to adults, and live and feed either internally or externally. Some are parasitoids of other parasitoids and some may even feed on their own species. Because they kill other insects, these wasps are extremely important for the control of pests of agricultural and forest crops, as well as vectors of human disease and veterinary pests. The economic importance of these wasps in pest management is unparalleled. They are widely used in biological control programs against major pests, with outcomes documented to result in decreases in pesticide use, increases in yield, and direct savings of billions of dollars through permanent pest control. Despite their importance, the evolutionary events leading to this enormous diversity are poorly understood, leading to an artificial system of taxonomic classification that hinders their further use in biological control.

     A central goal of this project was to directly address the evolutionary relationships across Chalcidoidea. To accomplish this, 989 genetic loci were extracted from specimens of more than 700 species, of which 520 species were chosen to develop the first comprehensive evolutionary hypothesis for Chalcidoidea. The resulting molecular phylogeny is being used to reorganize the classification of the group, which was previously distributed among 23 families and about 89 subfamilies. Combined with calibrations of the timing of major evolutionary events based on an excellent fossil record, we have a greatly increased understanding of the natural groups that comprise families and subfamilies of Chalcidoidea. This is providing a robust framework for a revised classification that can better predict the biology and host associations of the major family and subfamily groups. This revised classification is being summarized in a book on the 'Chalcidoidea of the World' based on the input of more 49 scientists from around the world.

     A second major goal of the project has been to move the Universal Chalcidoidea Database to a new platform, TaxonWorks (https://ucd.chalcid.org/). This comprehensive database contains complete records of the on taxonomic and biological information on all species of Chalcidoidea. TaxonWorks is an open source platform that will be curated by dozens of researcher. This authoritative resource is an essential tool for taxonomic experts, biological control researchers, and natural resource managers that are trying to get a better understanding of the distribution, host associations and behavior of this diverse group.

     A third main focus of this project was delivery of information on Chalcidoidea to the public, particularly K-12 educators (http://outreach.chalcid.org). In collaboration with university extension experts and local educators, we developed web pages geared towards education, with a focus on classroom learning and outreach. We stressed the economic benefits of chalcidoids, and the incredible diversity of their morphologies and life histories. We intend for this to be a continued and growing resource relevant to both the public, educators and researchers.

      In summary, using the funds provided by this award, we have made great progress in increasing our understanding of the minute parasitic wasps that form an important component of both natural and agricultural ecosystems.
